abstract.p: Letter from Brian Flack of New York Public Interest Research Group disputes assertion by New York State officials, in Apr 21 article, that state has reduced overall power-plant pollution by half from level in 1990

block.p: In ''Report Finds Power Plants Dirtier in '98'' (news article, April 21), New York State officials are cited as saying that the state has reduced overall power-plant pollution by half from the level in 1990. This assertion is inconsistent with data the Environmental Protection Agency emissions tracking system found on its acid rain database. According to the database, sulfur dioxide emissions far exceed half of 1990 levels; 1998 emissions (in tons) have been reduced by only 24 percent since 1990.

In ''Report Finds Power Plants Dirtier in '98'' (news article, April 21), New York State officials are cited as saying that the state has reduced overall power-plant pollution by half from the level in 1990. This assertion is inconsistent with data the Environmental Protection Agency emissions tracking system found on its acid rain database. According to the database, sulfur dioxide emissions far exceed half of 1990 levels; 1998 emissions (in tons) have been reduced by only 24 percent since 1990.

At a time when technology exists to cut these emissions, there is no reason why older, dirtier power plants should be exempt from meeting modern pollution standards. Power plants should comply with the same, strict emissions standards, regardless of their age or fuel type.
BRIAN FLACK Staff Attorney, New York Public Interest Research Group New York, April 22, 1999
